Author: Torankoku#4818
Content: kmd uses btc for security no? my question you, maybe not right group but is it possible for kmd security > btc security?

Author: Torankoku#4818
Content: or can btc and btc security be two separate things? sorry for my ignorance xD

Author: PHBA2061#2530
Content: in PoW, security is proportional to the "works" provided by miners, Bitcoin is the most secured but theoretically any PoW coin could become more secured than Bitcoin

Author: PHBA2061#2530
Content: for your 2nd question, ofc Bitcoin & Bitcoin security are 2 different things

Author: Torankoku#4818
Content: ah, thanks. so essentially, the point at which kmd security exceeds btc could be possible, is what you are saying

Author: PHBA2061#2530
Content: theoretically yes, if Komodo has enough hashpower.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: No not really... KMD needs a high hashrate coins to mooch off

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: What I meant about BTC being usless, as meant as currency... in context of the "hash wars" etc

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: if people use it as a currency mempool fills, and it breaks.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: IF it retains value, then its hash rate will remain high

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: and it is not useless in this case ... because dPoW can use it to secure other chains and data.... BUT without enough block reward at some point the hash rate will dissapear ...

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: 1-2MB blocks, cant have enough TXs in them to keep current mining profitabilty ...

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: that is a huge issue.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: unless BTC is litterally millions of dolalrs ... meaning it would cost your car to send $1 in fees ü§∑

Author: Torankoku#4818
Content: so if btc price is low, hashrate goes down due to no incentive to keep mining

Author: Torankoku#4818
Content: if hashrate goes down, then kmd loses value too?

Author: Torankoku#4818
Content: kmd value then is wholly dependent on btc, which is the current highest hashrate coin, is my understanding from this

Author: actionslacks#4072
Content: The value is not, the 51% attack prevention is.

Author: actionslacks#4072
Content: The valuation of any thing in crypto is completely subjective.

Author: actionslacks#4072
Content: And price can be controlled by whomever can print the fiat.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Or the tethers üòâ

Author: Torankoku#4818
Content: perhaps you misunderstand me, my apologies

Author: Torankoku#4818
Content: i am not trying to focus on price. im trying to understand true value of kmd

Author: Torankoku#4818
Content: if true value of kmd is protection of 51% attack prevention, this is dependent on hashrate no?

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: If the coin we are notarising to has a very low hash rate, and there exists enough hash power out there to easily 51% attack said coin, you would still need to over power noary nodes, who have easy diff mining, whilst in a short term attack, this is possible with enough hash rate, over a long period is quite impossible as far as I understand it.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: So even if BTC hash rate fell subsantially a 51% attack against coins secured by KMD notary nodes would still be ahrder to attack than coins not secured by notary nodes... And taking this further, if there does not exist a fork of BTC with anything near the current hash power of BTC... then crypto has lost the war against fiat and it doesnt really matter any more at this point.

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: More hashrate drives up difficulty , kmd retargets every block , notaries still mine on easy

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: not exactly ...

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: you can hit KMd with very high hash rate and mine blocks very fast in a row for a little time

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: but it would adjust within 50 blocks ... and then notaries would easy mine ... you would need to exponentially increase hash to maintain a 51%

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: even without a high hash rate coin notrised to, there is still a checkpoint in the KMD chain, so reorgs cannot happen, regardless if we notarise to BTC or ourself or any other coin for that matter.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if any blockchain has consistent TB blocks.... well it isnt very practical to use and how can you possibly sync to it? does anybody have 20gbps bandwidth to keep up with this chain? how can you possibly sync, even if you can keep up with the TB blocks? So a TB blocks blockchain is just silly at least for another few decades, which means relying on a TB chain for anything is also pretty silly

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if BTC hashrate falls, then some other chain will have higher hashrate. This can be deduced as there will be all that mining gear. so KMD would just switch to using whatever is the most secure chain
